stem: Dr. {{candidate_name}}, you are called to see a 65-year-old man on the surgical ward. He is 2 days post-laparotomy. He is pyrexial, hypotensive, tachycardic, and drowsy. How would you assess and manage this patient?

prompts.text: What is your initial assessment and diagnosis?
expectedKeyFacts: Suspect sepsis — SIRS + suspected infection
SIRS criteria: temp >38°C or <36°C, HR >90, RR >20, WCC >12 or <4
Sepsis: life-threatening organ dysfunction due to dysregulated host response to infection
qSOFA score: GCS <15, RR ≥22, systolic BP ≤100 mmHg
Two or more qSOFA criteria suggests sepsis
ABC assessment: airway, breathing, circulation
Identify source: abdominal, respiratory, urinary, wound, line-related

prompts.text: Describe your immediate management according to the Sepsis Six bundle.
expectedKeyFacts: Three in: oxygen, IV fluids, antibiotics
Three out: blood cultures, lactate, urine output
Oxygen: target SpO₂ 94-98% (or 88-92% if COPD risk)
IV fluid resuscitation: 500 mL crystalloid bolus, reassess
Broad-spectrum antibiotics within 1 hour (after cultures)
Blood cultures before antibiotics if possible
Lactate >2 mmol/L suggests tissue hypoperfusion
Monitor urine output — target >0.5 mL/kg/hr

prompts.text: The patient remains hypotensive despite 2 litres of fluid. What would you do next?
expectedKeyFacts: Consider septic shock — sepsis with persistent hypotension requiring vasopressors
Invasive monitoring: arterial line, central venous access
Commence vasopressor: noradrenaline first-line
Target MAP ≥65 mmHg
Assess fluid responsiveness: passive leg raise, stroke volume variation
Consider further fluid if responsive, avoid fluid overload
Involve ICU/critical care team urgently
Source control: surgical review if intra-abdominal source
Repeat lactate — trend indicates response to treatment

prompts.text: What is the rationale for early antibiotic administration in sepsis?
expectedKeyFacts: Each hour delay in antibiotics increases mortality
Broad-spectrum empirical therapy covers likely organisms
Tailor antibiotics once culture results available
Source control essential — antibiotics alone insufficient
De-escalate to narrow-spectrum once sensitivities known
Early goal-directed therapy improves outcomes
Time-critical intervention — 'door to antibiotics' <1 hour
Balance against antimicrobial stewardship

rescuePrompt: Perhaps you could tell me about the Sepsis Six — what are the three things you give and three things you measure?
keyFacts: Sepsis: organ dysfunction due to infection
SIRS criteria: temp, HR, RR, WCC
Sepsis Six: oxygen, fluids, antibiotics; cultures, lactate, urine output
Septic shock: persistent hypotension needing vasopressors

scoringGuidance.pass: Recognises sepsis, applies Sepsis Six systematically, knows time-critical nature of antibiotics, describes fluid resuscitation and escalation to vasopressors, involves ICU appropriately; stronger candidates discuss fluid responsiveness assessment and antimicrobial stewardship
scoringGuidance.borderline: Suspects sepsis but assessment not systematic, knows some elements of Sepsis Six but incomplete, vague on escalation or vasopressor choice
scoringGuidance.fail: Does not recognise sepsis, no knowledge of Sepsis Six or time-critical antibiotics, inappropriate fluid management, does not escalate care
